text:
Check http://213.46.22.12:8002 (my new web site in development, running at 
Apache 2.0.39, this url/port will be down if this issue is fixed). Click at the 
link "Site Map" at the left navigation bar. This HTML file is 129KB big. You 
will receive only the first 64KB part of this HTML file. This also occurs with 
some other pages (for example Files - Videokaarten - NVdia, which is 64.9KB 
big) and some images which are bigger than 64KB.

You can use http://213.46.22.12:8001 to compare with (this is the production 
web site, running by IIS5 of which I want to get rid of..).

I have tried it at three different computers: an IBM PC Server 520 (NT4 
Server), a simple Celeron900 server (Win2K Advanced Server), and my BP6 Dual500 
workstation (Win2K Pro, WinMe and Win98SE). I have also tried Apache 1.3.26, 
but this didn't solve the problem. I have tried to disable the firewall, also 
without success.

The most weird is that when the pages are loaded at the servers itself (I mean, 
http://localhost:8002) then the files bigger than 64KB will be displayed 
correctly! I really cannot find a solution, I was thinking about kinda caching 
problem, but I can't find the source. However I think that it's just a problem 
on my own side, which should be easy to solve, because I have never seen this 
major problem before, even not in this Bug Database..

The httpd.conf file can be downloaded here: http://213.46.22.12:8002/httpd.conf
creator: b.scholtz@chello.nl

text:
It sounds as if your firewall has modified the tcp/ip stack.

  Try setting the firewall's service to 'Disabled', restart the computer
  (so that perhaps it's tcp/ip drivers will not be loaded) and then attempt
  the same test.

  Failing that, please try removing the firewall software to determine if
  that is the cause of your problems.
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
Yes! The issue is fixed now!

I have tweaked the TCP/IP settings to the default/optimum using some articles 
at http://www.speedguide.net. I have added the DefaultTTL and changed the 
TcpWindowSize into the registry.

However, it was still weird that IIS5 worked OK when Apache didn't. Should be 
some 'Microsoft feature' I guess..

For that matter, the firewall used was a Sygate Personal Firewall Pro 4.2.

text:
I'm still having a similar problem with a clean install of Apache 2.0.52:
All html pages >64K repeat themselves after 64K.
Total file size is correct, though.

Apache 1.3.31 works fine.
Using Windows XP SP2.
No firewall is active (Zonealarm installed but shut down).
Connecting from localhost.
httpd.conf is standard.
Removal of optional modules does not help.
Directive Win32DisableAcceptEx does not help.
Happens with all current browsers, including Lynx.
Setting TCP/IP tweaks according to
http://www.speedguide.net/read_articles.php?id=157 does not help.

This seems a major problem, isn't it?

Have you ever tried to *uninstall* zone alarm?
Have you tried enablesendfile off and/or enablemmap off?
creator: nd@perlig.de
peterdebruin@heartandwings.nl
text:
Uninstalling ZoneAlarm doesn't help.
'enablesendfile off' doesn't help.
'EnableMMAP off' doesn't help.

Well. Just to make sure, you *did* reboot the box?

(I'm leaving the further research to the windows experts, I even don't have XP ...)
creator: nd@perlig.de
peterdebruin@heartandwings.nl
text:
Setting 'enablesendfile off' and rebooting solved it - restarting wasn't enough.
'enable mmap off' and 'Win32DisableAcceptEx' are not needed.

This should really be in the "Apache for windows" tutorial and in the default
configuration file, or at least in the comment lines, and the need for rebooting
should be mentioned.
Otherwise I wouldn't consider the problem "Closed".

The need for rebooting should also be stated in the 'enablesendfile' documentation.

BTW the problem existed for external access (not from localhost) as well.

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
The rebooting was needed because of the zone alarm (de)installation, not because
of enablesendfile.

Certainly not, I did reboot after that.
I added and removed 'enablesendfile off' several times and each time a reboot
was needed before it took effect.
It seems to influence some windows library initialization routine.

This should really be in the documentation and httpd.conf, I find a lot of
people on the web complaining about pictures being mishandled by Apache 2.0 on XP.
creator: peterdebruin@heartandwings.nl
